value: aava_1.0_score
description

The AAVA 2.0 metadata represents a significant structural evolution from AAVA 1.0 while preserving core semantic meaning. Major architectural changes include workflow structure reorganization and agent definition format changes that impact backward compatibility.
Core workflow purpose remains consistent - both versions define a data integration workflow for technical specifications and model updates. Agent functionality and business objectives are preserved.
AAVA 2.0 introduces hierarchical workflow structure with workFlowDetail wrapper and workflowAgents array, departing from flat nodes array structure in AAVA 1.0.
Root field 'workflowId' (line 2) renamed to nested 'workFlowDetail.id' (line 3) with value change from 1594 to 2147.
Root field 'workflowName' (line 3) renamed to nested 'workFlowDetail.name' (line 4) with format change from underscore to space separation.
Agent container changed from 'nodes' array (line 4) to 'workflowAgents' array (line 6) indicating conceptual shift in agent modeling.
Agent field 'agentName' (line 6) renamed to 'name' (line 8) removing semantic prefix.
New field 'agentId' introduced in AAVA 2.0 (line 7) providing unique agent identification not present in AAVA 1.0.
Agent field 'model' (line 7) renamed to 'modelDeploymentName' (line 9) with value evolution from 'gpt-4' to 'gpt-4.1'.
Tools structure completely reorganized from 'tools' array with string values (line 8) to 'toolReferences' empty array (line 11) indicating architectural change.
Agent task structure flattened from nested 'task' object (line 9) to direct 'description' field (line 10) removing task metadata wrapper.
AAVA 2.0 removes 'expectedOutput' field present in all AAVA 1.0 agents, reducing metadata completeness for output specifications.
Tools reference mechanism changed from populated string array to empty array structure, suggesting different tool integration approach.
Loss of detailed task structure including expectedOutput reduces governance metadata and specification completeness in AAVA 2.0.
AAVA 2.0 represents major version evolution with breaking changes requiring migration strategy for dependent systems.
Structural reorganization may break existing integrations expecting flat workflow structure and specific field names from AAVA 1.0.
Removal of tools array content and expectedOutput fields may impact systems relying on complete agent specifications.
AAVA 1.0 JSON is syntactically valid with consistent structure and complete agent definitions including all required metadata fields.
AAVA 2.0 JSON is syntactically valid with well-formed hierarchical structure, though some metadata fields are simplified or removed.
Both versions maintain identical agent descriptions indicating preserved functional requirements despite structural changes.
Agent count remains consistent at 3 agents across both versions maintaining workflow scope.
Empty toolReferences arrays in AAVA 2.0 create ambiguity about tool integration approach compared to explicit tool names in AAVA 1.0.
